subject: Re: [junit] ClasspathWalker (even better)
msgSnippet: ... I also assumed I d want to test for a collection of events.  I d just use something like: assertTrue(listener.heard(firstExpectedEvent));
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>>
>>public void testSomeClasspathVariation() {
>>
>> ClasspathWalker walker = new ClasspathWalker();
>> MockClasspathWalkerListener listener =
>> new MockClasspathWalkerListener();
>> walker.addListener(listener);
>>
>> walker.walkClasspath(someClasspathVariation)
>>
>> assertTrue(listener.heard(someExpectedEvent));
>>}
>
>
> I assumed that each different classpath variation gave rise to a collection of events,
> possibly diverse ones. That's why I jumped to the more granular tests. If each classpath
> variation maps to a single event, then there'd be no need to test "when I find this I
> generate that event" and it collapses to the above.
>

I also assumed I'd want to test for a collection of events. I'd just
use something like:

assertTrue(listener.heard(firstExpectedEvent));
assertTrue(listener.heard(secondExpectedEvent));
assertTrue(listener.heard(thirdExpectedEvent));

Each test method would test a different variation of the classpath, and
thus could expect different, and multiple, events.

I'm not saying this is THE way, it's just a way that has worked for me.
More and more I'm writing tests to verify behavior, not
classes/methods, and this approach is the first thing that comes to mind.

Mike
